target: Te kō me te ti'au'e.
source: The ant and the fly

target: E, i titahi 'ā, i 'una o titahi 'outu, me te 'animara mate i 'una
source: One day, on a rock strewn with animal carcasses

target: E kai 'a te kō, enā me te ti'au'e.
source: The ant was eating, and so was the fly.

target: Totohe 'aua no te’ā mea a 'aua e kai 'a
source: They quarreled over what they were eating.

target: Kaki te hoa te hope ke'ī, kaki mi a titahi.
source: One wanted the larger share, and so did the other.

target: Titotohe 'aua i 'una o te 'i'i o te 'animara.
source: They argued over which creature was stronger.

target: Te 'i'i o te kō, me te 'i'i o te ti'au'e.
source: The strength of the ant versus the strength of the fly

target: Pe'au te kō, mea 'i'i atu īa.
source: The ant said that she was stronger.

target: Pao, pe'au te ti'au'e : "A'o'e, mea 'i'i atu au."
source: Then the fly said, "No, I am stronger."

target: Pe'au te kō : "Mei te peu ati'i, ha'atupapahi te nei mea a taua."
source: The ant said, "If that’s the case, let’s settle this with a contest."

target: Ha'ati'a te ti’au’e e ha'atupapahi.
source: The fly accepted the challenge.

target: Tu'u 'a te ti'au'e i ta īa : "Mi 'Oui'a tihe i te Maratina."
source: The fly proposed: "From 'Oui'a to Maratina."

target: Pe'au te kō : "Mei 'Oui'a io he one i 'Omo'a."
source: The ant proposed: "From 'Oui'a to the beach at 'Omo'a."

target: Pe'au te ti'au'e : "Ati’i. E aha ta taua e 'ave ?"
source: The fly said, "Agreed. What should we take with us?"

target: Pe'au ai te kō : "E ke’ā. E 'ave au i tā’u ke’ā, mi 'Oui'a, e 'ave i no he one i 'Omo'a."
source: The ant replied: "A rock. I will carry my rock from 'Oui'a to the beach at 'Omo'a."

target: Pe'au te ti'au'e : "Mi a'u, e 'ave me au i tā'u ke’ā i no he one i 'Omo'a."
source: The fly said: "Me too, I will carry my rock to the beach at 'Omo'a."

target: Pe'au te kō : "E ! A epo naiho, ha'amata taua i te ha'atupapahi i tenā mea."
source: The ant exclaimed: "Come on, without waiting, let’s launch our challenge!"

target: 'Ave 'oe ta 'oe, 'ave au i tā'u.
source: You will carry yours; I will carry mine.

target: Te ke’ā Moturoio, oia’a ta te ti'au'e.
source: The rock Moturoio is the fly’s.

target: Ta te kō, e ke’ā ma'ita ka'uo'o.
source: The ant’s is a large white boulder.

target: E avai nei te’ā ke’ā, ma uta nei o te tohua popo.
source: The rock still lies there, just behind the soccer field.

target: Ua ha'ana'oa 'a te’ā ke’ā e te 'enana.
source: That rock was buried by man.

target: Tihetia mai o te kō me te ti'au'e, me ta ‘aua mou ke’ā, i te vahi pe’au’ia Moturoio i tenei, ua pō.
source: When the ant and the fly arrived, with their rock, at the place now called Moturoio, it was night.

target: U ha'ataime te ti'au'e.
source: The fly rested.

target: Te kō 'a a’o’e : mi te ma'ama, mi te po, e hana īa e.
source: The ant did not: by day as by night, she works.

target: Ua he'e anatu te kō me ta īa ke’ā.
source: The ant continued on her way with her rock.

target: Ua he'e, ua he'e, ua he'e, ua he'e te kō e e e.
source: She walked, she walked, she walked on, the ant...

target: Tihe te kō i Teatapu, ua 'una taime te kō 'ia'a
source: The ant reached Teatapu, where she took a brief pause.

target: Mi 'ia'a, he'e haka'ua te kō. I te ma'ama, ua tihe te kō i 'a'o nei me ta īa ke’ā.
source: From there, the ant set out again. At dawn, she arrived below in the village, with her rock.

target: U popahi te toa ti’au’e i titahi kape ti'au'e e hano ti'ohi i hea te kō me ta īa ke’ā.
source: The fly tasked one of his subordinates to go see where the ant and her rock were.

target: Te hanotia ti'ohi, a'e e 'itea mai i hea te kō me te ke’ā.
source: When he went to observe, he could not see where the ant and the rock were.

target: Ua he'e, ua he'e, ua he'e te'ā ti'au'e, e
source: The assigned fly marched, marched, marched...

target: Ua tihe te ti'au'e i te’ā taha e pe'autia nei, Ma'i'oifa'e
source: The fly arrived at the place now called Ma‘i‘oifa‘e.

target: Ua 'ite te ti'au'e mei 'una, i te kō me te ke’ā i no he one.
source: From the heights, the fly spotted the ant and her rock on the beach.

target: Ua 'ite i te kō 'i'a me ta īa ke’ā, i hua ai hua ti'au'e.
source: He saw the ant down there with her rock, and the fly immediately turned back.

target: Pe'au te’ā ti'au'e i tahipito tau ti'au'e : "Umo'i tatou e he'e."
source: The dispatched fly warned the others: "Let’s not go there."

target: Ha'ame'eme'ea tatou e te kō.
source: She will mock us.

target: Enā te kō ua tihe i no he one i 'Omo'a.
source: The ant has arrived on the beach at 'Omo'a.

target: Te’ā ke’ā, Moturoio, ua vai anaiho ïa i 'i'a'a. Mau anaiho ai te’ā ke’ā i'ā. A'i neke haka'ua.
source: As for the rock Moturoio, it remained where it was abandoned. Since then, it has never moved.

target: Ta te kō 'a, na te 'enāta i ha'ana'o i te ke’ā a te kō mi tai.
source: As for the ant’s rock, humans removed it from the shore.

target: Pe'autia i te’ā ke’ā ma hope iho nei “Ke’ā ha'ataimetina o Rataro.”
source: It was later called “Rataro’s Resting Rock.”
